questions.text: Which among the given options exhibits swarming behaviour?
All of the following are true regarding eukaryotic cells except?

options.label: A
options.text: Eukaryotic cells have a true nucleus, while prokaryotic cells do not.

options.label: B
options.text: Eukaryotic cells have membrane-bound organelles, whereas prokaryotic cells lack them.

options.label: C
options.text: Eukaryotic cells have linear DNA, whereas prokaryotic cells have circular DNA.

options.label: D
options.text: In eukaryotic cells, transcription and translation occur simultaneously, while in prokaryotic cells, they are separated by the nuclear membrane.

questions.correct_answer: D. In eukaryotic cells, transcription and translation occur simultaneously, while in prokaryotic cells, they are separated by the nuclear membrane.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Prokaryotic Cells

Eukaryotic Cells

Nucleus

No true nucleus, nucleoid region with circular DNA

True nucleus enclosed by a nuclear membrane

Size

Generally smaller (0.1-5.0 µm in diameter)

Generally larger (10-100 µm in diameter)

Organelles

Few organelles, no membrane-bound organelles.

Numerous membrane-bound organelles (e.g., mitochondria, ER).

Cell Wall

Present (peptidoglycan in bacteria, pseudo peptidoglycan in archaea)

Present in plants (cellulose) and fungi (chitin), absent in animals

Ribosomes

70S ribosomes

80S ribosomes in cytoplasm, 70S in mitochondria and chloroplasts

Genetic Material

Single circular DNA molecule, no histones, rarely introns present

Multiple linear chromosomes with histones, commonly introns, present

Gene Expression

Transcription and translation occur simultaneously in cytoplasm

Transcription occurs in the nucleus, translation in the cytoplasm

Reproduction

Asexual (binary fission)

Sexual and asexual (mitosis and meiosis)

Flagella

Simple, made of flagellin

Complex, 9+2 microtubule arrangement

Cytoskeleton

Absent or very simple

Complex cytoskeleton (microtubules, microfilaments)

Intracellular Movement

Generally absent

Present (vesicle transport, cytoplasmic streaming)

Plasma Membrane

No sterols (except in Mycoplasma)

Sterols (cholesterol in animals)

Protein Synthesis

Occurs in the cytoplasm

Occurs in the cytoplasm and on the rough ER

Metabolic Pathways

Various simple pathways, often anaerobic

Mostly aerobic pathways, complex metabolic processes

Examples

Bacteria, Archaea

Protists, fungi, plants, animals

questions.text: Which of the following spores are commonly used for sterilization control in hot air ovens?
questions.explanation:
Application

Bacterial Species

Autoclave sterilization
  • Clostridium tetani

Hot air oven sterilization
  • Bacillus subtilis

Steam sterilization
  • Bacillus stearothermophilus
  • Geobacillus stearothermophilus

Ethylene oxide sterilization
  • Bacillus atrophaeus

Sterility testing in pharmaceuticals and canned foods
  • Clostridium sporogenes

questions.text: Arrange the stages of spore formation (sporulation) in correct order:

options.label: A
options.text: Axial filament formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Maturation and lysis

options.label: B
options.text: Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Axial filament formation ➔ Maturation and lysis

options.label: C
options.text: Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Maturation and lysis ➔ Axial filament formation

options.label: D
options.text: Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Axial filament formation ➔ Maturation and lysis

questions.correct_answer: A. Axial filament formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Maturation and lysis

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is known for terminal spore formation?
questions.explanation:
Spore Location

Examples

Central

Bacillus anthracis, Bacillus cereus

Terminal

Clostridium tetani

Subterminal

Bacillus thuringiensis, Bacillus subtilis, Clostridium botulinum, Clostridium perfringens

questions.text: Arrange the layers of a spore from outside to inside in the correct order:

Identify the correct statements regarding fimbriae/pili from the list below: Fimbriae are made of subunits called fibrillins. Pili are involved in bacterial conjugation. Pili can be involved in motility through a process known as "twitching." Fimbriae play a role in pellicle formation at the liquid-surface interface. Pili are longer and more numerous than flagella.
questions.explanation:
Definition

Fimbriae are thin, hair-like appendages found on the surface of many bacteria, primarily Gram-negative bacteria.

Structure

Fimbriae are composed of protein subunits called pilins(Statement 1). They are usually shorter and more numerous than flagella. (Statement 5)

Types
  • Common (Type I) Fimbriae: Adhesive fimbriae that bind to mannose-containing receptors on host cells.
  • Sex Pili: Involved in bacterial conjugation and DNA transfer. (Statement 2)

Functions
  • Adhesion: Fimbriae allow bacteria to adhere to surfaces, cells, and tissues, which is crucial for colonization and infection.
  • Biofilm Formation: Contribute to biofilm formation, protecting bacteria from environmental stresses.
  • Gene Transfer: Sex pili facilitates the transfer of genetic material between bacteria during conjugation, promoting genetic diversity and the spread of antibiotic resistance.
  • Motility: Usually not involved except Type IV Pili, particularly in Neisseria species, enabling a type of movement known as twitching motility. (Statement 3)

Uses in Medicine
  • Target for Vaccines: Components of fimbriae can be used as antigens in vaccines to prevent bacterial infections.
  • Antimicrobial Targets: Inhibiting fimbrial function can prevent bacterial adhesion and biofilm formation, making it a potential target for new antibiotics.

Clinical Importance
  • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs): Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) use Type 1 fimbriae to adhere to the urinary tract, causing UTIs.
  • Respiratory Infections: Bacteria like Bordetella pertussis (whooping cough) use fimbriae to adhere to the respiratory tract.
  • Gastrointestinal Infections: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) use fimbriae to adhere to the intestinal mucosa, causing diarrhea.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Uses Type IV pili for surface attachment and biofilm formation.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Uses fimbriae for attachment to mucosal surfaces in the genitourinary tract.

Laboratory Identification
  • Hemagglutination Assay: Detects Type 1 fimbriae by their ability to agglutinate red blood cells.
  • Electron Microscopy: Visualizes fimbriae on the surface of bacteria.
  • Pellicle Formation: Observing pellicle formation on liquid culture surfaces can indicate the presence of fimbriae. (Statement 4)

questions.text: Leifson and Ryu's stain is used for staining which of the following?

Which of the following does not contain a polysaccharide capsule?
questions.explanation:
Capsulated Organisms

Polysaccharide Capsule

Exceptions
  • Pneumococcus
  • Meningococcus

  • Klebsiella pneumoniae (Option C)
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following organisms corresponds to the morphology of the image given?
Which of the following receptors is primarily responsible for recognising and binding to endotoxin?
Which of the following regarding lipopolysaccharides (LPS) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: LPS is primarily found in gram-positive bacterial cell walls.

options.label: B
options.text: LPS triggers an immune response through its lipid A component.

options.label: C
options.text: LPS is composed solely of proteins and does not contain any lipid or carbohydrate components.

options.label: D
options.text: LPS is composed of lipid A, lipoteichoic acid and O antigen

questions.correct_answer: B. LPS triggers an immune response through its lipid A component.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden high fever, low blood pressure, and an erythematous rash over her body. She reports nausea, vomiting, and muscle aches. On further questioning, she recalls using tampons during her recent menstrual cycle but forgot to remove one for several days. Laboratory investigations showed catalase-positive organisms arranged in clusters. All of the following are true about the cell wall of this bacterium except:
questions.explanation:
Gram-positive

Features

Gram-negative

Thick layer

Peptidoglycan layer

Thin layer

100 layer thick

Thickness

1–2-layer thickness

2-5 %

Lipid content

15-50%
  • Peptidoglycans
  • Lipoproteins
  • Teichoic acid

Composition
  • Lipopolysaccharide
  • Lipoproteins
  • Peptidoglycan

Absent

Outer membrane

Present

Absent

Periplasmic space + Porins

Present

Present

Teichoic acid (used for

attachment)

Absent

Present

Pentapeptide cross bridge

Absent

Present

NAM-NAG

Present

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, who underwent mitral valve replacement 3 months ago, presents with persistent fever, fatigue, and a new heart murmur. Blood cultures reveal gram-positive cocci, and echocardiography shows vegetations on the prosthetic valve. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Biofilm advantages:

  • Helps in adherence
  • Anti- phagocytic
  • Antibiotic resistance

Examples:

  • Streptococcus mutans
    • In mouth - cause dental caries
    • Forms a biofilm over the teeth.
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis - causes prosthetic heart valve endocarditis.
  • Biofilm is also shown by Pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fever and an eschar on his arm after handling animal hides. Which of the following methods is used to demonstrate the capsule of the causative agent?
